Register.name: cr2
Register.description: Control Register 2. Page Fault Linear Address

Flag.label: PWT
Flag.longmode: Not used if bit 17 of CR4 is 1

Flag.label: PCD
Flag.longmode: Not used if bit 17 of CR4 is 1

Flag.label: OSFXSR
Flag.description: Operating system support for FXSAVE and FXRSTOR operations

Flag.label: OSXMMEXCPT
Flag.description: Operating System Support for Unmasked SIMD Floating-Point Exceptions

Flag.label: UMIP
Flag.description: User-Mode Instruction Prevention (if set, #GP on SGDT, SIDT, SLDT, SMSW, and STR instructions when CPL>0)

Flag.label: FSGSBASE
Flag.description: Enables the instructions RDFSBASE, RDGSBASE, WRFSBASE, and WRGSBASE

Flag.label: OSXSAVE
Flag.description: XSAVE and Processor Extended States Enable

Flag.label: PKS
Flag.description: Enable Protection Keys for Supervisor-Mode Pages

Register.name: xcr0
Register.description: Can only be accessed if bit 18 of CR4 is set to 1. XGETBV and XSETBV instructions are used to access XCR0

Flag.label: SSE
Flag.description: XSAVE support for MXCSR and XMM registers

Flag.label: AVX
Flag.description: AVX enabled and XSAVE support for upper halves of YMM registers

Flag.label: BNDREG
Flag.description: MPX enabled and XSAVE support for BND0-BND3 registers

Flag.label: BNDCSR
Flag.description: MPX enabled and XSAVE support for BNDCFGU and BNDSATUS registers

Flag.label: opmask
Flag.description: AVX-512 enabled and XSAVE support for opmask registers k0-k7

Flag.label: ZMM_Hi256
Flag.description: AVX-512 enabled and XSAVE support for upper halves of lower ZMM registers

Flag.label: Hi16_ZMM
Flag.description: AVX-512 enabled and XSAVE support for upper ZMM registers

Register.name: dr0
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr1
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr2
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr3
Register.description: Can contain linear address of a breakpoint. If paging is enabled, it is translated to a physical address

Register.name: dr6
Register.description: Permits the debugger to determine which debug conditions have occurred

Flag.description: Indicates, when set, that the associated breakpoint condition was met when a debug exception was generated
Indicates, when set, that the associated breakpoint condition was met when a debug exception was generated
Indicates, when set, that the associated breakpoint condition was met when a debug exception was generated
Indicates, when set, that the associated breakpoint condition was met when a debug exception was generated
Indicates that the next instruction in the instruction stream accesses one of the debug registers
Indicates, when set, that the debug exception was triggered by the single-step execution mode (enabled with TF bit in EFLAGS)
Indicates, when set, that the debug instruction resulted from a task switch where T flag in the TSS of target task was set
Indicates, when set, that the debug exception or breakpoint occurred inside an RTM region

Register.name: dr7
Register.description: A local breakpoint bit deactivates on hardware task switches, while a global does not. Condition 00b means execution break, 01b means a write watchpoint, and 11b means a R/W watchpoint. 10b is reserved for I/O R/W (unsupported)

Register.name: gdtr
Register.description: Stores the segment selector of the GDT

Register.name: ldtr
Register.description: Stores the segment selector of the LDT

Register.name: idtr
Register.description: Stores the segment selector of the IDT

Register.name: xmm0
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.name: xmm1
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.name: xmm2
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.name: xmm3
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.name: xmm4
Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.

Register.description: A SIMD register. Under SSE, this register can be used to store four 32-bit single-precision floating point numbers. SSE2 would later expand its usage to also allow two 64-bit double-precision floating point numbers, two 64-bit integers, four 32-bit integers, eight 16-bit short integers, or sixteen 8-bit bytes or characters.
